title: No Corrections: June 8, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 8, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 8, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greta Rybus and Galen Koch and Greta Rybus
title: Shearing Sheep, and Hewing to Tradition, on an Island in Maine
description: In a remote area of Maine, the Wakeman family maintains the traditions of island shepherding, the cycles of which have been largely unchanged for centuries.
content: With travel restrictions in place worldwide, we’ve launched a new series, The World Through a Lens, in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Greta Rybus shares a collection of photographs from a set of islands in Maine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Hessney
title: ‘Air Travel Surges 123%’: A Lesson About Misleading Statistics
description: In this lesson, students learn about why percentage change values may give a misleading impression of what is really happening.
content: Featured Article: “Air Travel Surges by 123%! (Beware of Misleading Data Like That)” by Neil Irwin
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: U.S. Protests, Europe’s Reopening, J.K. Rowling: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inside Day Cares, Post-Covid
description: A glimmer of hope for wary parents.
content: As more day cares and preschools re-open across the country, some parents are understandably wary of sending their kids back into the unknown. Alyssa Abkowitz, whose 3-year-old daughter returned to preschool in mid-May, called child care centers across the country to ask what a day will look like in a post-coronavirus world. Precautions include: frequent sanitizing of play structures, toys and lunchboxes; individual desks and materials for kids; and masks for teachers and caretakers (and sometimes students).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.2 Million Homes in California
description: A Colonial Revival house in Long Beach, an octagonal home in Marin County and a 1915 Cape Cod at the base of the Hollywood Hills.
content: Built in 1935, this house was designed by Kirtland Cutter, a Pacific Northwest architect who was known for his colonial homes and contributed a building to the 1893 World’s Fair. The site plan and front sculpture garden were done by Ralph D. Connell, a landscape architect responsible for the grounds of the University of California, Los Angeles, as well as the La Brea Tar Pits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: ‘A Uniquely American Moment’ in California
description: Monday: Marqueece Harris-Dawson, a Los Angeles councilman, talks about why protests haven’t died down.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey and John Eligon
title: Minneapolis Will Dismantle Its Police Force, Council Members Pledge
description: Saying the existing Police Department cannot be reformed, a majority of the City Council has promised to rethink public safety from the ground up in the wake of George Floyd’s killing.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Nine members of the Minneapolis City Council — a veto-proof majority — pledged on Sunday to dismantle the Police Department, promising to create a new system of public safety in a city where law enforcement has long been accused of racism.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Stocks Recoup 2020 Losses: Live Markets Updates
description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
content: Stocks on Wall Street erased their losses for the year, a remarkable milestone for a market that was reeling just a few months ago as investors feared the damage caused by the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Padilla
title: Older Adults Remain Isolated Despite Reopening. These Programs Help.
description: Volunteer efforts have popped up across the country to help ease the lingering isolation of the pandemic among older Americans, creating connections and unexpected friendships.
content: Sally Love Saunders, 80, was stuck in a retirement home in San Francisco, desperate for someone to teach her to use Zoom so she could connect with people outside the building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Hiroko Masuike
title: George Floyd, Defunding, Stock Rally: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Growing a Family in the Shadow of a Pandemic
description: Six households weighed the risks of conceiving and carrying a child during the coronavirus outbreak, each balancing their concerns against an uncertain future.
content: The threat of coronavirus has tormented us in many ways, but perhaps this is one of the most profound: Deciding whether to start or expand a family has suddenly become even harder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Shirts Were Red. The Fans Were All White.
description: As sports try to improve the spectacle of games in empty stadiums, the myth and mystery of Arsenal’s North Bank mural offers an idea, and a warning.
content: The story of the Arsenal mural has drifted, over the years, into something more closely resembling a myth. What should be straightforward details are now shrouded in fog, tangled by apocrypha.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Someone Found a Buried Treasure Hidden in the Rocky Mountains
description: Forrest Fenn, a New Mexico art collector, created a treasure hunt in 2010. Over the weekend, he said, someone found the chest he had buried with gold nuggets, coins, gems and artifacts.
content: After 10 years, a chase for hidden treasure in the Rocky Mountains has come to an end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Just as Air Travel Is Picking Up, U.K. Imposes a Quarantine
description: The decision by Boris Johnson has enraged airlines, frustrated travelers and bemused public health experts, who wonder how it can be enforced.
content: LONDON — When the coronavirus was spreading at breakneck speed this spring, Britain’s government flatly refused to quarantine travelers, even those arriving from virus hot spots like Spain or Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee and Ben Smith
title: Axios Allows Its Reporters to Join Protests
description: In a company memo, the chief executive of the politics news site said he supported staff members’ right to march, adding that the publisher would cover bail for any employee who is arrested.
content: In an unusual move at a news media organization, the head of Axios, a site popular with Beltway insiders, said in a memo that the company would support staff members who take part in public protests, a shift from the stance journalists normally adopt to avoid the appearance of partisanship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Barbara
title: Brazil Is in Coronavirus Free Fall
description: Hospitals are on the brink of collapse, cemeteries are burying people in mass graves, and still, we refuse to take this virus seriously.
content: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — It’s been almost three months since my toddler left the apartment. We’ve been enduring as best as we can: We spend countless afternoons at the balcony watching the street and counting red cars; we open and close all the curtains; we pile up boxes of paper tissues and make mountains; we invent stories about our neighbors based on the smells of their cooking. Recently, she has started to play with her own shadow. This was a wise move, since both of her parents are exhausted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker and Matt Furber
title: Bail Is at Least $1 Million for Ex-Officer Accused of Killing George Floyd
description: Derek Chauvin is charged with second-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter in Mr. Floyd’s death.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — The white police officer charged with murder in the killing two weeks ago of George Floyd, a black man whose death in custody led to nationwide protests, was given a bail of as much as $1.25 million on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: A Black Man Is Killed by a Trooper. His Family Wants Answers.
description: Maurice Gordon, 28, was shot by a white officer after a traffic stop on the Garden State Parkway, two days before the death of George Floyd.
content: Maurice Gordon’s mother and sister were at home in London when the call came.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Restaurant Dumplings Want a Place in Your Freezer
description: The Manhattan restaurants Northern Tiger and 3 Times now sell their dumplings, frozen, for takeout or delivery.
content: Frozen Chinese dumplings ready to heat are not new, especially in grocery stores in Chinese neighborhoods, but two Manhattan restaurants now sell them for pickup or delivery. Northern Tiger, the counter-style spot at Hudson Eats in Brookfield Place near the World Trade Center, has introduced kits of dumplings now being made at Wayla, their sibling restaurant. The dumplings are to be boiled, then pan fried and served with accompanying sauces. The wrappers are parchment-thin and the fillings like chicken and wood ear mushrooms, tasty. Another restaurant, 3 Times, with locations on the Lower East Side and near Union Square, offers more than a dozen different frozen dumplings, including Shanghai soup dumplings, less common pork and rice dumplings wrapped in leaves, and crunchy little radish pancakes, all to steam or fry.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Someone Found a Buried Treasure Hidden in the Rocky Mountains

title: Changing Police Culture
description: A professor of psychology urges adoption of the Ethical Policing Is Courageous training program. Also: Missing Broadway theater.
content: To the Editor:

description: A professor of psychology urges adoption of the Ethical Policing Is Courageous training program. Also: Missing Broadway theater.

author: By The New York Times
title: Man Drives Into Seattle Protest, Flees While Brandishing Gun
description: A person drove into a crowd of Seattle protesters on Sunday night, authorities said, and one person was shot.
content: A person drove into a crowd of Seattle protesters on Sunday night, authorities said, and one person was shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin, Alexander Burns and Thomas Kaplan
title: Biden Walks a Cautious Line as He Opposes Defunding the Police
description: As gruesome videos and energetic protests reshape public opinion about racial discrimination, Joe Biden tried to balance protesters’ calls for a law enforcement overhaul while not alienating moderate voters.
content: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. staked out a careful position on Monday in support of a law enforcement overhaul but not defunding police departments, rebutting a new Republican attack line as he tries to harness growing activism against systemic racism while not alienating protesters or more moderate voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz, Claire Cain Miller and Quoctrung Bui
title: When 511 Epidemiologists Expect to Fly, Hug and Do 18 Other Everyday Activities Again
description: Even experts need to make personal decisions about what risks are worth it in the age of coronavirus. For some, life will never be the same again.
content: Even experts need to make personal decisions about what risks are worth it in the age of coronavirus. For some, life will never be the same again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey
title: What Would Efforts to Defund or Disband Police Departments Really Mean?
description: Much is not yet certain, but here’s what is known so far about some efforts to defund or abolish police departments.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Across the country, calls are mounting from some activists and elected officials to defund, downsize or abolish police departments. A veto-proof majority of the Minneapolis City Council pledged on Sunday to dismantle the Minneapolis Police Department, promising to create a new system of public safety in a city where law enforcement has long been accused of racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: No, the Jobs Report Wasn’t Rigged. Here’s What Happened.
description: The pandemic has complicated the usual methods and models for compiling employment data. But uncertainty has been offset by transparency.
content: When the Labor Department reported on Friday that employers had added jobs in May and that the unemployment rate had unexpectedly fallen, economists were surprised.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: Despite Recession, Stock Markets Turn Positive for the Year
description: The S&P 500 climbed back above where it began the year on the same day that economists said the United States fell into a recession in February.
content: And just like that, we’re back to where we started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Nicole Perlroth and Matthew Rosenberg
title: Amid Pandemic and Upheaval, New Cyberthreats to the Presidential Election
description: Fear of the coronavirus is speeding up efforts to allow voting from home, but some of them pose security risks and may make it easier for Vladimir V. Putin, or others, to hack the vote.
content: With the general election less than 150 days away, there are rising concerns that the push for remote voting prompted by the pandemic could open new opportunities to hack the vote — for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, but also others hoping to disrupt, influence or profit from the election.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Other Movements Have Faded. This One ‘Feels Like Home.’
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 8, 2020.
content: “My entire life has changed since taking to the streets.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Sunday’s Protests in New York
description: Demonstrators marched under sunny skies in Brooklyn and Manhattan during the 11th day of protests in New York as a curfew was lifted.
content: Demonstrators marched under sunny skies in Brooklyn and Manhattan during the 11th day of protests in New York as a curfew was lifted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Tropical Storm Cristobal Hits Louisiana and Florida
description: The storm made landfall in southeast Louisiana, causing storm surges, flooding and heavy rain.
content: The storm made landfall in southeast Louisiana, causing storm surges, flooding and heavy rain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Sunday’s Protests in New York
description: Demonstrators marched under sunny skies in Brooklyn and Manhattan during the 11th day of protests in New York as a curfew was lifted.
content: Demonstrators marched under sunny skies in Brooklyn and Manhattan during the 11th day of protests in New York as a curfew was lifted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Lady Gaga’s ‘Chromatica’ Is Her Sixth No. 1 Album
description: Her long-awaited return to dance-pop opened with the equivalent of 274,000 sales, the largest yet for a female artist this year.
content: Lady Gaga’s latest album, “Chromatica,” has topped this week’s Billboard album chart — the latest laurel in a long career comeback, and an affirmation of Lady Gaga’s superstar status amid the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: How to Reduce Credit Card Fraud
description: There’s been an explosion in online credit card fraud. Here’s how you can protect yourself.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Schiesel
title: With Real-Life Games Halted, Betting World Puts Action on E-Sports
description: Computer-vs.-computer games of FIFA livestream to gamblers on Twitch. Fantasy contests carry League of Legends lineups. In the coronavirus age, video games have grown into a darling for casinos.
content: Marco Blume, trading director for the sports book Pinnacle, remembers when betting on the competitive video games known as e-sports was an exotic concept.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Bon Appétit Editor Adam Rapoport Resigns
description: The move comes hours after a photo of him resurfaced on social media, drawing condemnations from the staff for a stereotypical depiction of Puerto Ricans.
content: Adam Rapoport, the editor in chief of Bon Appétit magazine, resigned on Monday, hours after a 2004 photo of him and his wife, Simone Shubuck, resurfaced on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Prince Andrew and U.S. Prosecutor in Nasty Dispute Over Epstein Case
description: The spat over whether the prince is willing to help in a sex-trafficking inquiry escalated, with a top federal prosecutor effectively calling the British royal a liar.
content: For four months, federal prosecutors in New York have been locked in a nasty public spat with Prince Andrew of Britain about what they say is his refusal to aid their investigation into allegations of sex trafficking and other crimes by the financier Jeffrey Epstein and his associates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: As the Art World Goes Online, a Generation Gap Opens
description: Young collectors are still viewing and buying pieces, but they’re spending far less time and money than their older counterparts once did. That’s a problem for the industry.
content: LONDON — What with everything else that’s going on, international art collectors might seem like the last people we should worry about right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Refinery29 Editor Resigns After Former Employees Describe ‘Toxic Culture’
description: The editor, Christene Barberich, said she had decided to leave after reading accounts by black women and other women of color who said they had faced discrimination at the company.
content: The women’s lifestyle publication Refinery29 is the latest media organization to undergo a change in leadership during the cultural reckoning that has accompanied the widespread protests against racism and police violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Pinkowski
title: A Living Library Filled With Killer Bacteria
description: Britain’s National Collection of Type Cultures, a library of human bacterial pathogens, turned 100 this year.
content: In the winter of 1915, Pvt. Ernest Cable arrived at the Number 14 Stationary Hospital in Wimereux, France, in bad shape. The British army’s soldiers stationed on the Western Front of World War I were being ravaged by a variety of microscopic enemies. For Private Cable, it was Shigella flexneri, the bacterium that causes dysentery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Jewelry Inspired by Farm Living
description: Janet Mavec designs gold rings, necklaces and earrings with food themes.
content: Janet Mavec, who once had a store on Madison Avenue, makes jewelry that she sells online. Most of the pieces, including necklaces, pendants, charms, bracelets, pins and earrings, are inspired by what’s on her farm in Pottersville, N.J. The items are made from 18-karat gold plate over brass and range in price from $30 to $1,800. In addition to enhancing your accessory wardrobe or that of a food lover, you might consider the owl necklace ($155) for a graduate. Each piece of jewelry comes with a recipe from Ms. Mavec’s farm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: Will Work for Room
description: After the coronavirus put him out of work and he fell behind on rent, a Brooklyn resident came up with a plan to work for his landlord.
content: For Kurt Juergens, a musician who used to rely on babysitting gigs to pay his rent, the coronavirus has been a problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Remembrances of Lunches Past
description: “One Last Lunch,” edited by Erica Heller, lets authors imagine meals with the dearly departed.
content: Erica Heller, the daughter of the novelist Joseph Heller (“Catch-22”), describes an imagined lunch at the original Union Square Cafe with her dad, in “One Last Lunch.” It’s the first of 50 fairly brief chapters about final meals, invented by writers and others, with people they loved. So you also have Daniel Bellow with his father, Saul, at Barney Greengrass; and Elizabeth Mailer and her father, Norman, at Elephant & Castle. Not all involve relatives, but given the number of fathers, the book would make a fine Father’s Day gift. There’s also Sara Moulton, the chef, imagining lunch with her mentor, Julia Child; and Bob Balaban, the actor, sharing lunch at Lindy’s with Groucho Marx. The book was Ms. Heller’s idea, and it ends with another lunch, an acrimonious one, that she imagined with her father at the new Union Square Cafe. It took her more than two years to chase down the subjects and get them to submit their pieces. As for who did not come through, “I could have killed for Mike Nichols,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: How to Feed Crowds in a Protest or Pandemic? The Sikhs Know
description: Their centuries-old faith tradition of nourishing anyone in need has found new energy and purpose in America’s turmoil.
content: Inside a low, brick-red building in Queens Village, a group of about 30 cooks has made and served more than 145,000 free meals in just 10 weeks. They arrive at 4 a.m. three days a week to methodically assemble vast quantities of basmati rice, dal, beans and vibrantly flavored sabzis for New York City hospital workers, people in poverty and anyone else in search of a hot meal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: BTS Fans Say They’ve Raised $1 Million for Black Lives Matter Groups
description: The fund-raising campaign led by fans of the K-pop group was energized this weekend as protests continued worldwide after the death of George Floyd in police custody in Minneapolis.
content: Fans of the K-pop boy band BTS have raised more than $1 million for Black Lives Matter, the Movement for Black Lives and more than a dozen other civil rights and advocacy organizations, a fan group said on Sunday, as protests against police brutality and systemic racism continued worldwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Man Who Drove Into Protesters Said He Was a K.K.K. Leader, Prosecutors Say
description: Harry H. Rogers drove into a group of demonstrators near Richmond, Va., on Sunday, the authorities said. The county prosecutor called him “an admitted leader of the Ku Klux Klan.”
content: A man drove a vehicle into a group of protesters outside Richmond, Va., on Sunday, the authorities said, and identified himself as a leader of the Ku Klux Klan. Prosecutors said they were investigating the episode as a possible hate crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Jesse Drucker and David Enrich
title: Hospitals Got Bailouts and Furloughed Thousands While Paying C.E.O.s Millions
description: Dozens of top recipients of government aid have laid off, furloughed or cut the pay of tens of thousands of employees.
content: HCA Healthcare is one of the world’s wealthiest hospital chains. It earned more than $7 billion in profits over the past two years. It is worth $36 billion. It paid its chief executive $26 million in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: The Long History of the ‘Outside Agitator’
description: Amid widespread protests over police brutality after the death of George Floyd, some federal and local officials have blamed outsiders for stoking violence. Similar claims were made during the civil rights movement.
content: After demonstrations for racial equality in Alabama were inflamed by the killing of Jimmie Lee Jackson, 26, a black activist who was shot by a state trooper, state officials issued a resolution asking people to stay home, citing “continued agitation and demonstrations led and directed by outsiders.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezekiel J. Emanuel and Paul A. Offit
title: Could Trump Turn a Vaccine Into a Campaign Stunt?
description: In a desperate search for a boost, he could release a coronavirus vaccine that has not been shown to be safe and effective as an October surprise.
content: Oct. 23, 2020, 9 a.m., with 10 days before the election, Fox New releases a poll showing President Trump trailing Joe Biden by eight percentage points.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Bradley Fields, Magician Who Favored Warmth Over Flash, Dies at 68
description: Mr. Fields was an actor, mime, illusionist and educator who equated magic with pure wonder, not trickery. He died of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Democrats Unveil Sweeping Bill Targeting Police Misconduct and Racial Bias
description: The measure, the most expansive intervention into policing that lawmakers have proposed in recent memory, is likely to draw opposition from Republicans and police unions.
content: WASHINGTON — Democrats in Congress on Monday unveiled sweeping legislation aimed at combating excessive use of force and racial discrimination by the police and making it easier to identify, track and prosecute misconduct, the most expansive federal intervention into law enforcement that lawmakers have proposed in recent memory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Prince Andrew and U.S. Prosecutor in Nasty Dispute Over Epstein Case
description: The spat over whether the prince is willing to help in a sex-trafficking inquiry escalated, with a top federal prosecutor effectively calling the British royal a liar.
content: For four months, federal prosecutors in New York have been locked in a nasty public spat with Prince Andrew of Britain about what they say is his refusal to aid their investigation into allegations of sex trafficking and other crimes by the financier Jeffrey Epstein and his associates.
source.name: The New York Times

The British army’s soldiers stationed on the Western Front of World War I were being ravaged by a variety of microscopic enemies. For Private Cable, it was Shigella flexneri, the bacterium that causes dysentery.

title: As the Art World Goes Online, a Generation Gap Opens
description: Young collectors are still viewing and buying pieces, but they’re spending far less time and money than their older counterparts once did. That’s a problem for the industry.
content: LONDON — What with everything else that’s going on, international art collectors might seem like the last people we should worry about right now.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Democrats Unveil Police Reform Bill
description: Mourners gathered to view George Floyd in Houston. Protests were held in cities including Los Angeles, New York and Charlotte, N.C., but nighttime demonstrations were largely quiet.
content: Two weeks after George Floyd was killed in Minneapolis, demonstrations against police violence continued to fill the streets of cities and towns across the country on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Falwell’s Blackface Tweet Brings Racial Dissent to Liberty University
description: A tweet by Liberty University’s president, Jerry Falwell Jr., has sparked an angry protest in the evangelical college’s community and a rare apology from Mr. Falwell.
content: WASHINGTON — The racial strife roiling the country and its politics has reached an unlikely redoubt of social conservatism, Jerry Falwell Jr.’s Liberty University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 5, Episode 6 Recap: Fake It Till You Make It
description: Bobby has already made it, of course. But if there’s money or status involved, he just can’t help himself. And he’s not the only one.
content: Fakes, forgeries, phonies, fugazis — they’re all very much on the brain of this week’s crackerjack episode of ‘Billions.’ For some characters, faking it is all they know how to do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Aishvarya Kavi
title: Romney Marches With Protesters in Washington
description: The senator from Utah appeared to be the first Senate Republican to join the demonstrations over the killing of George Floyd, putting himself at odds with the president again.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitt Romney of Utah marched with demonstrators toward the White House on Sunday, appearing to be the first Republican senator to join the thousands across the country protesting the death of George Floyd in police custody.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Wamsley
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘The Bachelor: the Greatest Seasons’ and ‘Amélie’
description: A look back at Sean Lowe’s journey to find love on ABC. And a beloved French film from Jean-Pierre Jeunet is available for streaming.
content: THE BACHELOR: THE GREATEST SEASONS — EVER! 8 p.m. on ABC. By the beginning of June, fans of the “Bachelor” franchise had hoped to be following the adventures of Clare Crawley, the Season 16 bachelorette whose journey was expected to premiere on May 18. But with “The Bachelorette” and “Bachelor in Paradise” indefinitely postponed because of the coronavirus, viewers can rewatch scenes from past “Bachelor” seasons instead. First up is Sean Lowe’s season, which aired in 2013.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: Concerns About Preterm Birth Extend to the Last Few Weeks
description: Infants born at 37 or 38 weeks were more likely to have developmental delays than full-term babies.
content: When I was training in pediatrics, back in the 1980s, we spent a lot of time working in the newborn intensive care unit, where relatively new — and rapidly evolving — technologies made it possible to save extremely premature infants. A full-term pregnancy lasts for 40 weeks, and we were often taking care of babies born at 27 or 28 weeks, and sometimes earlier, impossibly tiny infants who were clearly not ready to exist outside the womb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: 10 Racehorses Killed in Fiery Crash on New Jersey Turnpike
description: One of the horses was sired by the Triple Crown winner American Pharoah and another by the Belmont Stakes winner Tonalist.
content: Ten racehorses on their way from Florida to New York were killed early Sunday morning when the tractor-trailer they were riding in hit a concrete median on the New Jersey Turnpike and burst into flames, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: About Those Job Numbers …
description: The markets rarely get it as wrong as they did last week. Economists tried to explain why better-than-expected labor data wasn’t part of a conspiracy.
content: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Are the Police Attacking Protesters?
description: This is what happened when a fortified police line met a wave of peaceful demonstrators in New York.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $2.2 Million in California
description: A Colonial Revival house in Long Beach, an octagonal home in Marin County and a 1915 Cape Cod at the base of the Hollywood Hills.
content: A Colonial Revival house in Long Beach, an octagonal home in Marin County and a 1915 Cape Cod at the base of the Hollywood Hills.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Protests in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
description: The 11th day of protests began with two goals already achieved: the mayor lifted the curfew and pledged to divert funding from the police.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

title: 7 Thrillers to Read This Summer
description: Distract yourself with the preposterous predicaments of the protagonists in these books this summer.
content: Distract yourself with the preposterous predicaments of the protagonists in these books this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Evelyn Caro, Nurse Who Realized a Lifelong Dream, Dies at 69
description: Nearing 50, with her children grown, she went back to school and became a nurse. She came out of retirement only to die of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Our Best Reads for World Oceans Day
description: Most of our planet is covered by water. Here’s what going on in that vast part of the planet as global temperatures climb.
content: More than 70 percent of the planet’s surface is covered by the oceans. For World Oceans Day, here’s a look at some of our best coverage of the state of the sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Rosés by the Six-Pack
description: The many shades and flavors of rosé are explored in two mixed cases.
content: When it comes to rosés, I’m still learning what regions, grapes and producers I really like. Which is why I think a mixed case is a great idea. Victoria James, the beverage director at Cote, a Korean steakhouse, has selected six rosés of varying intensity from California, France and Italy. You get two of each in the case sold at Convive Wines & Spirits in the East Village. It comes with a signed copy of her book “Drink Pink: A Celebration of Rosé.” At Pure Liquid Wine & Spirits in the Westfield World Trade Center, a six-pack of rosés representing Chile, France, Germany, Italy and Portugal has been assembled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Kevin Hart on How White America Needs to Help End Police Brutality
description: “The highest level of anger and frustration should be attached to this.”
content: “The highest level of anger and frustration should be attached to this.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman and Lauren Hard
title: Will CrossFit Survive?
description: CrossFit inspires extreme devotion. Now it’s repelling sponsors, gym affiliates and alienating its community.
content: On Sunday, about 50 black owners of CrossFit affiliate studios joined a Zoom conference call with Greg Glassman, the chief executive of CrossFit. They represent a small percentage of the owners of the more than 14,000 gyms around the world that pay $3,000 a year to use that name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: The TikTok House Wreaking Havoc Next Door
description: Neighbors say the party boys of Sway House are not a welcome addition to the block.
content: When a group of young men moved into a 7,800-square-foot mansion on a quiet street in the Bel Air section of Los Angeles in late January, their new neighbors took notice. Some assumed they were tech entrepreneurs. How else could they afford rent?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: New Zealand, BTS Fans, Global Recession: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. Outlines Steps for Training Camp, but Timeline Unclear
description: The training camps were scheduled to start in late July.
content: The N.F.L. has outlined the steps teams must take before players can return to training facilities, the latest attempt by the league to return to business as usual in an off-season that has largely been conducted virtually.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: Boxed Lunches and Plexiglass Will Welcome Back Wall Street’s Workers
description: The finance industry will return to its offices this month, but the landscape is likely to be altered for many months to come.
content: Grab-and-go packaged meals may replace midday generous buffets and three-figure lunches. Plexiglass could divvy up trading floors the size of football fields. Heat maps, accessible on a mobile app, will help identify the restrooms with the smallest crowds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Alexander
title: America, This Is Your Chance
description: We must get it right this time or risk losing our democracy forever.
content: Our democracy hangs in the balance. This is not an overstatement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson Tebbe, Micah Schwartzman and Richard Schragger
title: The Quiet Demise of the Separation of Church and State
description: The government is allowing federal pandemic aid to pay for clergy salaries, something that once would have been unthinkable.
content: The First Amendment’s Establishment Clause prohibits the government from making any law “respecting an establishment of religion.” This has long been thought to prohibit direct government support for religion. The contours of that idea have been contested, and they have contracted over time. But the commitment to some form of separation of church and state has endured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
title: The Palestinian Plan to Stop Annexation: Remind Israel What Occupation Means
description: Officials in the West Bank say they are willing to let the Palestinian Authority collapse if Israel applies its sovereignty over occupied territory.
content: RAMALLAH, West Bank — The Palestinian Authority says it will cut the salaries of tens of thousands of its own clerks and police officers. It will slash vital funding to the impoverished Gaza Strip. And it will try any Israeli citizens or Arab residents of Jerusalem arrested on the West Bank in Palestinian courts instead of handing them over to Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: The Challenges of Pandemic Dental Care
description: “We always did a lot with respect to personal protective equipment and keeping the office clean, and now we’re tweaking what we already did to be even safer.”
content: On March 20, when Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York ordered nonessential businesses closed, a colorful sign appeared in the window of my dentist’s office. It reads, “We are still here for you! Call our office if you are having dental pain or an emergency.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: The Challenges of Pandemic Dental Care
description: “We always did a lot with respect to personal protective equipment and keeping the office clean, and now we’re tweaking what we already did to be even safer.”
content: On March 20, when Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York ordered nonessential businesses closed, a colorful sign appeared in the window of my dentist’s office. It reads, “We are still here for you! Call our office if you are having dental pain or an emergency.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman and Lauren Hard
title: Will CrossFit Survive?
description: CrossFit inspires extreme devotion. Now it’s repelling sponsors, gym affiliates and alienating its community.
content: On Sunday, about 50 black owners of CrossFit affiliate studios joined a Zoom conference call with Greg Glassman, the chief executive of CrossFit. They represent a small percentage of the owners of the more than 14,000 gyms around the world that pay $3,000 a year to use that name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
title: The Palestinian Plan to Stop Annexation: Remind Israel What Occupation Means
description: Officials in the West Bank say they are willing to let the Palestinian Authority collapse if Israel applies its sovereignty over occupied territory.
content: RAMALLAH, West Bank — The Palestinian Authority says it will cut the salaries of tens of thousands of its own clerks and police officers. It will slash vital funding to the impoverished Gaza Strip. And it will try any Israeli citizens or Arab residents of Jerusalem arrested on the West Bank in Palestinian courts instead of handing them over to Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: The Idea: Build It, and They Can Find Coronavirus Tests
description: Three start-up veterans who created an online directory of testing sites are among a wave of volunteers contributing to the virus fight.
content: For the past two months, the 9-to-5 jobs at their recruiting software company were just the start of a busy workday for Joe Essenfeld, Boris Kozak and Matt Geffken.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Furious Backlash in Brazil After Ministry Withholds Coronavirus Data
description: President Jair Bolsonaro’s government stopped disclosing comprehensive data on coronavirus cases and deaths as cases continue to soar.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — As the coronavirus tore through Brazil, President Jair Bolsonaro came under blistering criticism for sabotaging the isolation measures imposed by states, encouraging mass rallies by his supporters and lashing out on the soaring death toll, saying, “What do you want me to do?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: New Zealand, BTS Fans, Global Recession: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní, Jeffery C. Mays and Ashley Southall
title: Defying Police Unions, New York Lawmakers Ban Chokeholds
description: Legislators, responding to protests over the death of George Floyd, are approving a package of bills aimed at police misconduct.
content: Inspired by the protests sweeping the state and nation, New York legislative leaders on Monday began to approve an expansive package of bills targeting police misconduct, defying longstanding opposition from law enforcement groups, including police unions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: New Pro Sports Venture Puts Women’s Sports in the Players’ Hands
description: Athletes Unlimited’s idea, which predated the pandemic, is to play a short season at one location, emphasizing individuals and online storytelling. No team owners, home cities or even fixed rosters.
content: Athletes Unlimited did not plan to begin a new league amid a pandemic, nor did it anticipate its new league would be perfect for such a situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: What the Heck Is That?
description: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
content: An air force base — also known as an air base — is an airdrome used for the operation of military aircraft. Its common initialism is A.F.B.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: When the Police Lie
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: An encounter in Buffalo last Thursday — in which two police officers shoved a 75-year-old man to the ground and left lying him there while blood poured out of his ear — was troubling partly because of the original police account.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Harmon and Rick Rojas
title: A Delicate Balance: Weighing Protest Against the Risks of the Coronavirus
description: As the protests against police brutality continue, public officials are warily watching for signs that mass demonstrations are leading to virus outbreaks.
content: None of the plans for how the nation might safely emerge from the coronavirus lockdown involved thousands of Americans standing shoulder to shoulder in the streets of major cities or coughing uncontrollably when the authorities used tear gas to disperse them. No one planned on protesters being herded into crowded prison buses or left in crowded cells.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Choi
title: A Facebook Post Lands an Innocent Woman in Jail in This Riveting Debut Novel
description: A young woman’s reaction on social media to a terrorist act seals her fate in “A Burning,” by Megha Majumdar, a novel set in Kolkata that examines the effects of power on the powerless.
content: A BURNINGBy Megha Majumdar
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tess Taylor
title: A Poet of Found Language Who Finds Her Language in Archives
description: Susan Howe’s new book, “Concordance,” pastes together collages of word and thought from old letters, manuscripts and (yes) concordances.
content: CONCORDANCE By Susan Howe
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Chanel’s First Digital Show Was a Disappointment on Many Levels
description: The French brand unveiled its virtual cruise collection. I miss the rocket ships.
content: The first big digital fashion show of the pandemic era — which is to say, the first big show since real shows were canceled — was unveiled on June 8. It followed a weekend in which protests against police brutality and racism sparked by the killing of George Floyd proliferated not just in the United States, but around the world. And it came as more cities and countries gingerly tiptoed their way toward reopening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Protesters, Everywhere (Including … Mitt Romney?)
description: Huge demonstrations and a rethinking of the Minneapolis police: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Protests spread into the heartland, newsrooms grapple with how to cover them and prominent Republicans consider ditching Trump. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy and Kim Barker
title: Other Protests Flare and Fade. Why This Movement Already Seems Different.
description: The massive gatherings for racial justice across the country and now the world have achieved a scale and level of momentum not seen in decades.
content: DENVER — Ever since people across the country began pouring into the streets to protest police violence, Dakota Patton has driven two hours each day to rally on the steps of the Colorado State Capitol. He has given up his gig jobs delivering food and painting houses. He is exhausted. But he has no plans to leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Senior
title: Is This the Trump Tipping Point?
description: I know. We’ve said we’ve been here a thousand times before. This time feels different.
content: You never want to say that you’ve reached a tipping point with this administration. Donald J. Trump has proved to be the Nosferatu of American politics: heartless, partial to Slavs, beneath grace and thus far impervious to destruction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: ‘People Are Getting in Planes’: The Travel Business Is Picking Up
description: After months of staying at home during the pandemic, Americans are heading to vacation destinations like Florida and national parks.
content: The nation’s largest airlines are preparing for a limited rebound next month as more Americans book vacations in places like Florida and the mountains and national parks in the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Goldbaum
title: One Hospital. One Virus. The Fear Won’t End for These Doctors.
description: ‘If this is spared, I don’t want to know what not spared looks or feels like.’
content: While Philadelphia managed to avoid the sort of coronavirus surge experienced in New York, the pandemic still pushed one hospital to the brink. In the above video, the doctors, nurses and workers at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital show the strain the outbreak is putting on them and their mental health.
source.name: The New York Times

title: One Hospital. One Virus. The Fear Won’t End for These Doctors.
description: ‘If this is spared, I don’t want to know what not spared looks or feels like.’
content: ‘If this is spared, I don’t want to know what not spared looks or feels like.’
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Biden Pours Millions Into Facebook Ads, Blowing Past Trump’s Record
description: Joe Biden spent $1.6 million on Facebook last Thursday as his campaign capitalized on energy surrounding mass protests. That’s far more than President Trump has spent on the platform on a single day.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign has moved to capitalize on the enormous energy reflected in the nationwide protests against racism and police brutality with the biggest online spending of his candidacy, pouring nearly $5 million into Facebook ads alone in recent days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Anno Domino’ Review: Long Married, but Open to Adjustment
description: In his new audio comedy, Alan Ayckbourn does more than write: He and his wife, Heather Stoney, portray several couples in disarray.
content: Ella is, to be frank, a perfectly dreadful human being — casually bigoted, wantonly unpleasant, the sort of parent who fawns extravagantly over one child and habitually belittles the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez
title: In Houston, Thousands Wait in the Heat to Pay Respects to George Floyd
description: People lined up for hours to view the body of a man who died in police custody in Minneapolis — a man who was one of them in so many ways.
content: HOUSTON — Most did not know him. But they knew the city that shaped him, and that was enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: Returning to Work on the Subway? Here’s What You Need to Know
description: As riders prepare to start riding the trains again during New York City’s initial reopening, the safety of public transit is a big question.
content: When the coronavirus pandemic swept across New York City, over 90 percent of the subway’s 5.5 million daily riders abandoned the system — an icon of urban crowding turned into a symbol of the threat that a deadly virus posed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: New Zealand Lifts Lockdown as It Declares Virus Eliminated, for Now
description: Saying the country had no active coronavirus cases and no new infections, officials declared that the strict clampdown on public life would end.
content: Crowds will gather again in New Zealand’s restaurants. Weddings will include as many hugs and guests as the happy couple wants — and even social distancing will not be needed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Senate Moves Toward Preserving Public Lands, and Political Careers
description: Despite some resistance within their ranks, Republicans are pushing a popular public lands bill that could help endangered colleagues, with an eye toward protecting their majority in November.
content: WASHINGTON — Gathered with a few Senate colleagues and President Trump in the Roosevelt Room of the White House back in February, Senator Cory Gardner gazed up at a portrait of the room’s eponymous president in his Rough Rider regalia and saw an opening to change Mr. Trump’s mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louise Aronson
title: For Older People, Despair, as Well as Covid-19, Is Costing Lives
description: ‘This is like being in prison.’
content: Earlier this month, a colleague who heads the geriatrics service at a prominent San Francisco hospital told me they had begun seeing startling numbers of suicide attempts by older adults. These were not cry-for-help gestures, but true efforts to die by people using guns, knives and repurposed household items.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: N.Y.C. Begins Reopening: Here’s What It Looks Like
description: After months of a devastating outbreak, the city is officially back in business, with as many as 400,000 people returning to work.
content: Michael Gilsenan celebrated the first day of New York City’s reopening by treating himself to coffee and cheesecake at his neighborhood bakery in Greenwich Village.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The U.S. Entered a Recession in February
description: The pandemic forced the economy to contract sharply, ending a record expansion and prompting the group that dates U.S. business cycles to formally declare a recession.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States economy officially entered a recession in February 2020, the committee that calls downturns announced on Monday, bringing the longest expansion on record to an end as the coronavirus pandemic caused economic activity to slow sharply.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Global Coronavirus Caseload Passes 7 Million
description: The W.H.O. warned that the pandemic appeared to be worsening, and said that asymptomatic transmission was not a significant factor in how the virus spreads. China is using Twitter to drown out criticism during the pandemic.
content: The World Health Organization reported on Monday that the number of new daily cases worldwide had hit a new high on Sunday, a sign that the pandemic appeared to be worsening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong, Aaron Krolik, Paul Mozur, Ronen Bergman and Edward Wong
title: Behind China’s Twitter Campaign, a Murky Supporting Chorus
description: Swarms of accounts are amplifying Beijing’s brash new messaging as the country tries to shape the global narrative about the coronavirus and much else.
content: As the Trump administration lashes out at China over a range of grievances, Beijing’s top diplomats and representatives are using the president’s favorite online megaphone — Twitter — to slap back with a pugnaciousness that is best described as Trumpian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Jim Huylebroek
title: For Decades, This Radio Station Named the Dead. Few Still Listen.
description: Afghans once tuned into Radio Afghanistan twice a day to hear the reading of death notices. But in an age of social media, the voice of the nation has lost much of its sway.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Through decades of coups, invasions and endless war, Afghans tuned their radios to Radio Afghanistan every morning at 7 and every afternoon at 4:05 to hear the names of the newly dead.
source.name: The New York Times
